name: Fox-640
keyboard: QWERTY Style keyboard with Numeric Keypad
description:
A.Becket says in its site :

''One of the most interesting Apple ][ clones I have seen. This machine claims to be a "Multi-System" computer, and the manual speaks of future advancements, allowing other systems to be housed. Basically, it is an Apple ][ with a Z80 Card, which can boot into CP/M or Apple ][ software. Instead of saying APPLE ][ on boot, it says -:FOX:-''

Source : The as-yet unnamed compute museum

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>We can spot here the 6 (?) expansion slots (Apple II compatible) and the 2 cpu : the 6502 (for Apple II compatibility) and the Z80 (for CP/M compatibility).<p class="petitgris"><a href="http://pcmuseum.i-o.net.au/" target="_blank">The as-yet unnamed compute museum</a></p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The columbia MPC is shipped with fully suported software that will save you $3,000. Included is the entire self-teaching Perfect Software family: Perfect Writer, a word processor; Perfect Speller, a 50,000 word dictionnary; Perfect Filer, a data base manager; and Perfect Calc, a financial calculation system.<br><br> In addition, you get MS-DOS, CP/M-86, Macro/86 assembler, BASICA, Asynchronous communication support, Diagnostics and the Columbia Tutor program...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET  - PAGE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>... from Australia<p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>We can see here the Palcom PX-7 with all its Pioneer extensions : the graphic tablet, the Laser Disc player, a joystick and even the TV is a Pioneer !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTERS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Yeno DPC 64 leaves major of MSX"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote>In June 1983, IBM was still seeking independant programmers.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666" The envelope please.<br> There's an acceptance letter inside. And a check that could have your name on it. (If we select your program, that is.)<br> But remember. We pick our winners carefully... </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN THE KITCHEN...</strong></font><br><blockquote>A TO-7 in the kitchen? For sure it makes smile the woman!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems quite happy with her new MB-H1 !<br> Do you think japanese girls used to bring their H1 to school ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #3 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The guy on the right is "Sidney", a well known french break dancer back in 1984 !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Soichiro Oga / <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Old PC leaflets museum</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM."  <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMOTECH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (APRIL 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <http://www.classiccmp.org/dunfield/miscpm/" target="_blank">Dave Dunfield</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
